title: VC Daily: How Venture Capital Is Spreading Across the Country
text:
Venture capital raised by startups in Los Angeles stayed flat in 2021's fourth quarter at $5.7 billion after two consecutive quarters of decline from $6.5 billion in the year's first quarter. The area logged a large share of early-stage deals as a proportion of overall deals for the full year.

Atlanta saw venture funding drop three consecutive quarters last year—from roughly $1.6 billion in the first quarter to $514 million in the fourth. However, the area notched a record 74 deals in the final quarter, up from 54 in the first.

Denver broke its previous quarterly funding record last year after startups based there netted roughly $2.3 billion in capital in the fourth quarter, a 64% increase from its previous record set in the second quarter.

And now on to the news ...

Top News

AI interview. Databricks Ventures, launched in December by Databricks Inc., aims to invest in young companies developing data and artificial-intelligence systems that work with its parent's Databricks Lakehouse data repository and analytics platform.

Andrew Ferguson, head of the new venture arm, is leading the strategic investment effort. Early this month, Databricks Ventures made its first investment, joining in a $110 million Series D funding round of Labelbox Inc., a training data platform for enterprise machine-learning applications.

Mr. Ferguson talked with WSJ Pro about the Lakehouse Fund, the unit's first, and the effort to identify startups that can contribute to Databricks' "lakehouse" ecosystem. In the past, more common data repositories required companies to make copies of their data so that it could be structured and analyzed in a separate environment. A lakehouse allows users to analyze data in the repository itself, according to Databricks, a startup valued at $38 billion.

Click here to read edited excerpts from the interview.

8.1%

China's GDP growth in 2021, though momentum slowed in the fourth quarter. (WSJ)

Warburg Pincus Seeks $2 Billion Fund to Extend Hold for Duravant

Growth investor Warburg Pincus LLC is seeking up to $2 billion for Duravant LLC in a single-asset secondary transaction that will give the firm more time and money to manage the company, according to people familiar with the offering, WSJ Pro's Preeti Singh reports. The deal is expected to close in early February, the people said. Warburg acquired the Downers Grove, Ill.-based Duravant in 2017 and agreed to sell a portion of its majority stake to Carlyle in October last year. It didn't disclose the terms of the deal, but the transaction valued Duravant, which provides engineered equipment and automated solutions to various industries including food processing, at about $5.5 billion, a source familiar with the transaction said.

Meet the Investor Who Spots Opportunities for Jeffrey Katzenberg

When he was growing up in Los Angeles, Anthony Saleh said he found entrepreneurial inspiration in the VHS cassettes of Walt Disney Co. classics such as "The Little Mermaid" and "Aladdin." After receiving the tapes for his birthday, he would rent them out to friends for 25 cents a night. At the time, Mr. Saleh gave no thought to the company behind those movies, or the executive, Jeffrey Katzenberg, then largely responsible for their production throughout the 1980s and 1990s. Yet more than 25 years later, it is Mr. Saleh whom Mr. Katzenberg is turning to for help plotting a course out of the rubble formed when his first post-Hollywood venture, Quibi, imploded, The Wall Street Journal's Erich Schwartzel reports. Mr. Saleh, 35 years old, has been Mr. Katzenberg's point of entry to the early-stage technology companies the mogul is evaluating far outside the Hollywood bubble, both men said.

Industry News

Funds

Human Capital is raising $500 million for its fifth fund, according to a regulatory filing. Recent Human Capital investments include healthcare services provider Transcarent, debit-card startup Point and speech software developer Sanas.ai Inc.

People

Divvy Homes, a homebuying startup that helps renters transition into homeowners, appointed John Lee as chief operating officer, and promoted Lucia Franzese to chief revenue officer and Shirley Lin to chief product officer. Mr. Lee was most recently a managing director in the private equity group at Blackstone. Ms. Franzese and Ms. Lin joined Divvy in 2019 and 2021, respectively. San Francisco-based Divvy Homes is backed by Andreessen Horowitz, Caffeinated Capital, GGV Capital and others.

Small-business insurance provider NEXT Insurance appointed Teodora Gouneva to the post of chief financial officer. She succeeds Michelle Cheung, who becomes chief corporate officer. Ms. Gouneva previously held positions at PayPal and Airbnb. Last year, Palo Alto, Calif.-based NEXT Insurance raised a $250 million funding round led by FinTLV Ventures and Battery Ventures at a $4 billion valuation.

Exits

Deel, a payroll and compliance software provider for international teams, acquired Roots, an HR software platform for remote organizations, for an undisclosed amount. Deel also hired Casey Bailey to lead HR at the company. In October, San Francisco-based Deel said it raised a $425 million Series D round from Coatue Management, Altimeter Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, Y Combinator Continuity, Spark Capital and Neo, valuing the company at $5.5 billion. Roots previously secured funding from Right Side Capital Management and Forum Ventures.

New Directions Behavioral Health purchased digital behavioral health company Tridiuum for an undisclosed sum. Tridiuum was backed by GoPhillyFund, Sopris Capital, Fresenius Medical Care Ventures and Martinson Ventures.

New Money

Bolt Financial Inc., a San Francisco-based e-commerce checkout startup, scored $355 million in Series E funding led by BlackRock, giving the company a valuation of $11 billion. New investors Schonfeld Strategic Advisors, Invus Opportunities, H.I.G. Growth Partners and CE Innovation Capital also participated in the round, along with existing backers Activant Capital and Moore Strategic Ventures.

Lukka, a New York-based crypto-asset software and data provider, closed a $110 million Series E round, valuing the company at more than $1.3 billion. Marshall Wace led the investment, which included additional support from Miami International Holdings Inc., Summer Capital, SiriusPoint Ltd., Soros Fund Management, Liberty City Ventures and S&P Global.

Pinwheel, a New York-based payroll data connectivity platform, nabbed a $50 million Series B round led by GGV Capital. Previous backers Coatue Management, First Round Capital and Upfront Ventures also joined in the funding, along with new investors AMEX Ventures, Kraken Ventures, Franklin Templeton and others.

BlocPower, a Brooklyn, N.Y.-based startup that retrofits aging urban buildings with energy-efficient electric heating and cooling systems, picked up a $30 million investment from Microsoft Corp.'s Climate Innovation Fund.

EVage, an Indian electric commercial vehicle startup, was seeded with a $28 million investment from RedBlue Capital. General Partners Prescott Watson and Olaf Sakkers will join the company's board.

A55, a financing platform currently serving Brazil and Mexico, secured a 92.8 million Brazilian real ($16.3 million) Series B investment. Led by Movile, the round included participation from Mouro Capital.

Daasity, a San Diego-based e-commerce analytics and data platform used by consumer product brands, landed $15 million in Series A funding. VMG Catalyst led the investment, which included contributions from Cove Fund, Exeter Capital, 1855 Capital, Mooring Ventures, Okapi Venture Capital and Serra Ventures.

FitLab Inc., a Newport Beach, Calif.-based fitness platform, completed its Series A round, bringing the total raised by the company to $15 million. The company also acquired fitness app Fitplan and overnight running relay series Ragnar for an undisclosed amount. FitLab's investors include Two Styx Capital, Cava Capital, Snoop Ventures, Audie Attar of Paradigm Sports Management and Courtney Reum of M13. Fitplan previously raised funding from Lerer Hippeau, Bullpen Capital and Imaginary Ventures.

Verica, a continuous verification startup helping make systems more reliable and less vulnerable to costly incidents, snagged $12 million in Series A funding. Lead investor Intel Capital was joined by True Ventures and Mango Capital in the round.

ChromaWay AB, a Stockholm-based developer of blockchain technology platforms, fetched a $10 million investment led by True Global Ventures 4 Plus.

Giddy, a Draper, Utah-based crypto investing app, gathered an $8 million seed investment led by Pelion Venture Partners.

Fintech Farm, a London-based creator of neobanks in emerging markets, secured a $7.4 million funding round from investors including Flyer One Ventures, TA Ventures, u.ventures and AVentures Capital.
